Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Magnetic Mobile Micro-Robotic Swarms using Smart Magnetic Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop methods for modeling, design and control of a large number of magnetic mobile micro-robots for a given specific application. Here, micro-robots are proposed to be made of novel smart magnetic composites for remote, parallel magnetic actuation and control in two dimensions and three dimensions in small confined spaces such as inside the human body, a micro-fluidic chip, and small desktop workspaces. The research will result in methods which are general enough to apply across all magnetic micro-robotic systems and that can be exploited in diverse applications. Deliverables include a catalog of fundamental modeling, analysis, design and fabrication tools, demonstration and validation via hardware, documentation of research results, and engineering student education.

If successful, the results of this research will provide an opportunity to create new micro-robotic systems for use in health-care, microfluidic bio-devices, tissue engineering, programmable matter, and desktop micro-manufacturing applications. The results will be disseminated to allow the creation of commercial micro-robotic devices for medical, bioengineering and micro-manufacturing applications. Graduate and undergraduate engineering students will benefit through classroom instruction and involvement in the research. The research results of the project will be presented to children, K-12 students, K-12 teachers, IEEE student members, and college students through public lectures. The achievements of the project will be also exhibited in science museums for educating the public and children on micro-robotics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to develop new methodologies for design, fabrication and control of a large number of untethered mobile micro-robots for robust and controlled operation for future micron-scale manufacturing and medical applications. To achieve such objective, we have created new methods in micro-robotic swarm design, modeling, actuation, fabrication, control, and functions. We have chosen remote magnetic actuation approach for such micro-robots, where micro-robots have been made of hard magnetic materials integrated with their polymeric body material. We have shown programmable 3D pick-and-place assembly of heterogeneous microparts, such as hydrogels, silicon pieces, and fibers, by mobile magnetic micro-robots with a capillary force-based gripping method. Next, we designed and fabricated soft magnetic miniature robots that can have programmed shapes and motion in 3D using remote magnetic fields. For this, we developed a general design and fabrication methodology for creating new soft magnetic milli/micro-robots with programmable shape changes. Such robots can have multiple locomotion modes and manipulate objects in the environment. Moreover, we used two-photon lithography-based 3D nano-printing method to create complex magnetic micro-robots, which can have dexterous and precise 6-DOF motion control. Finally, we have also demonstrated programmable self-assembly of mobile magnetic micro-robotic swarms at the air-water interface. Such micro-robotic collectives are used to navigate in complex media and manipulate complex objects robustly. 

 

The project findings have been reported in major scientific and engineering journals and conferences. During this project, the principle investigator also created and published the first textbook on mobile micro-robotics with the MIT Press, which would be used in teaching and introducing such newly emerged robotics field. The project has trained graduate students on mobile micro-robotics and self-assembly topics. The findings in this project made significant impacts on micro-robotics and programmable self-assembly fields mainly. They would also impact active matter, self-assembly, and materials science fields. Above magnetic micro-robotic swarms would be used in medical and desktop manufacturing applications in the future, which would improve the welfare of our society. 

 


Last Modified: 03/10/2019
Modified by: Metin Sitti
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aims to develop new methodologies for design, fabrication and control of a large number of untethered mobile micro-robots for robust and controlled operation for future micron-scale manufacturing and medical applications. To achieve such objective, we have created new methods in micro-robotic swarm design, modeling, actuation, fabrication, control, and functions. We have chosen remote magnetic actuation approach for such micro-robots, where micro-robots have been made of hard magnetic materials integrated with their polymeric body material. We have shown programmable 3D pick-and-place assembly of heterogeneous microparts, such as hydrogels, silicon pieces, and fibers, by mobile magnetic micro-robots with a capillary force-based gripping method. Next, we designed and fabricated soft magnetic miniature robots that can have programmed shapes and motion in 3D using remote magnetic fields. For this, we developed a general design and fabrication methodology for creating new soft magnetic milli/micro-robots with programmable shape changes. Such robots can have multiple locomotion modes and manipulate objects in the environment. Moreover, we used two-photon lithography-based 3D nano-printing method to create complex magnetic micro-robots, which can have dexterous and precise 6-DOF motion control. Finally, we have also demonstrated programmable self-assembly of mobile magnetic micro-robotic swarms at the air-water interface. Such micro-robotic collectives are used to navigate in complex media and manipulate complex objects robustly. The project findings have been reported in major scientific and engineering journals and conferences. During this project, the principle investigator also created and published the first textbook on mobile micro-robotics with the MIT Press, which would be used in teaching and introducing such newly emerged robotics field. The project has trained graduate students on mobile micro-robotics and self-assembly topics. The findings in this project made significant impacts on micro-robotics and programmable self-assembly fields mainly. They would also impact active matter, self-assembly, and materials science fields. Above magnetic micro-robotic swarms would be used in medical and desktop manufacturing applications in the future, which would improve the welfare of our society.
